Hi Chirs,

Usually if you have "scope leakage" you should check transitive and additionalScopeFocus filters.
Transitive filter allows you to configure what TYPE of links, that are usually out of a scope, 
should be part of the scope. Example of these documents are embeds, speculative links (usually 
javascript), or redirects.

If you don't want any of transitive filters just set them to zero:
max-speculative-hops: 0
max-referral-hops: 0 	
max-embed-hops: 0

Additional Scope focus allows you to specify what links (not type of links) are to be crawled.
As now this filter is set to match links' suffixes (usually file extensions.)


Example:
Seed: http://a.com/
Scope: HostScope
additionalScopeFocus: .*\.gif (crawl all gif images)
Transitive filters turned off.

All urls from a.com are part of the scope therefore crawled:
http://a.com/index.html (CRAWLED)
http://a.com/a.gif (CRAWLED)
....

All urls that end with '.gif' will be crawled:
http://b.com/b.gif (CRAWLED)
http://c.com/link-to-a-gif-image (NOTCRAWLED)
http://b.com/b.jpg (NOTCRAWLED)

As you can see http://b.com/b.jpg and http://c.com/link-to-b.gif-from-c are not being crawled but 
they are links to images (maybe <img src="http://b.com/b.jpg"> <img 
src="http://c.com/link-to-b.gif-from-c">)
Now, if you want to crawl these links you can set transitive embeds to 1 and they will be crawled 
because of their type.

Take care.
i.
